general: This law changes how court cases are handled. It makes sure that when a judge reviews a decision, they can only look at specific parts of the decision and not the whole thing. This will help speed up the process of reviewing decisions and make it easier for judges to decide which parts of a decision should be changed or kept the same. The law also says that some decisions made by a higher court called the Upper Tribunal cannot be challenged in court. Additionally, the law allows for more paperless and digital hearings in courts and tribunals to make the process more efficient and environmentally friendly.

series.short: "New UK Law Limits Judicial Review and Strengthens Tribunal Decisions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 allows for quashing orders to be made by the Upper Tribunal, which can include provision for the quashing not to take effect until a specified date or for removing or limiting any retrospective effect of the quashing.
* Simplified point 2: The Act also provides that the Upper Tribunal's permission-to-appeal decisions are final and not subject to judicial review in any other court.
* Simplified point 3: The Act excludes the supervisory jurisdiction of the High Court or the Court of Session in relation to certain decisions of the Upper Tribunal, such as decisions involving questions of jurisdiction or procedural defects.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by the Act do not apply to decisions of the Upper Tribunal made before the day on which the Act comes into force.

series.short: Automatic Online Conviction: A Streamlined Process for Summary Offenses
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The automatic online conviction option is an alternative to the traditional court process for certain summary offences.
* Simplified point 2: The automatic online conviction option is only available for offences that are not punishable with imprisonment, and the accused must have attained the age of 18 years when charged.
* Simplified point 3: The qualifying conditions for the automatic online conviction option are specified in regulations made by the Lord Chancellor, and include requirements such as the accused having attained the age of 18 years when charged and the required documents having been served on the accused.
* Simplified point 4: The offender is liable to a fine of the amount specified for the offence, and may also be liable to other penalties such as penalty points, compensation, prosecution costs, and a surcharge.
* Simplified point 5: The Lord Chancellor has the power to make regulations about penalties etc under section 16I, and these regulations may specify different amounts of fines, compensation, prosecution costs, and surcharges for different offences.
* Simplified point 6: The timing and status of conviction and penalty are determined in accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules, and the conviction is treated as if it had been imposed by the specified magistrates' court.
* Simplified point 7: The notice of conviction and penalty is an electronic notification that sets out each penalty imposed on the offender and specifies a magistrates' court for the purposes of section 16K.
* Simplified point 8: The magistrates' court may set aside a conviction if it appears to the court that the conviction is unjust, and may also exercise powers to set aside any penalty imposed on the person under section 16I.
* Simplified point 9: The extension of single justice procedure to corporations is made by substituting "or is not an individual" after "charged" in subsection (1)(b) of section 16A of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980.

series.short: "Written Indications of Plea: Procedures and Consequences"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation allows for a person charged with an offense to indicate their plea in writing instead of appearing in court.
* Simplified point 2: The section outlines the procedures for the accused to indicate their plea in writing, including providing information about the charge and the consequences of giving or failing to give a written indication of plea.
* Simplified point 3: If the accused gives a written indication of a guilty plea, the court must proceed in accordance with section 17ZB. If the accused gives a written indication of a not guilty plea, the court must proceed in accordance with section 17ZC or section 18(1A).
* Simplified point 4: If the accused fails to give a written indication of plea, the court must proceed by way of a hearing for the purposes of section 17A.
* Simplified point 5: The section also provides for the withdrawal of a written indication of plea and the procedures for such withdrawal.
* Simplified point 6: The section applies to a person charged with an offense who has attained the age of 18 years at the time of charging or attains the age of 18 years after being charged.

series.short: "Accused's Right to Trial by Jury in Crown Court"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation allows for a person who has given a written indication of a guilty plea to be sent to the Crown Court for trial, without a formal hearing, if the court is satisfied that it is highly likely that the person would be convicted and sentenced to imprisonment.
* Simplified point 2: The court must provide the person with information about the consequences of being sent to the Crown Court for trial, and ask if they object to being sent. If the person does not object, and the prosecutor does not object, the court will proceed with the trial in the Crown Court.
* Simplified point 3: If the person pleads not guilty at the summary trial, the trial and the plea are void and the court will proceed as if the hearing were for the purposes of section 17A and the accused had indicated that they would plead not guilty.

series.short: "Opting Out of Summary Trials: Rights and Elections for Written Allocation Proceedings"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section allows for a person accused of a scheduled offense to indicate non-consent to a summary trial and instead opt for a written allocation proceeding.
* Simplified point 2: The section requires the court to provide the accused with information about the options available to them, including the option to indicate non-consent to a summary trial and the option to elect for a written allocation proceeding.
* Simplified point 3: The section provides that if the accused does not indicate non-consent to a summary trial, the court must proceed with the trial in accordance with section 18 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998.
* Simplified point 4: The section allows for the court to make elections for written allocation proceedings and provides for the information that must be provided to the accused in relation to those elections.
* Simplified point 5: The section provides that if the accused elects to be tried by the Crown Court, the court must proceed in accordance with section 51 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998.
* Simplified point 6: The section allows for Criminal Procedure Rules to make provision about circumstances in which the section does not apply.

series.short: "Option to Reject Summary Trial Without Allocation Hearing Granted to Accused"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The accused now has the option to reject a summary trial without an allocation hearing.
* Simplified point 2: If the accused is present in court, they must be explained the option to indicate non-consent to summary trial, and if they choose to do so, they will be sent to the Crown Court for trial without the opportunity to make representations or obtain an indication of sentence.
* Simplified point 3: If the accused is not present in court, their legal representative must be asked if the accused would wish to indicate non-consent to summary trial.
* Simplified point 4: If the accused or their legal representative gives an in-court indication of non-consent to summary trial, the court must proceed in relation to the offence in accordance with section 51 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998.
* Simplified point 5: If the accused or their legal representative does not give an in-court indication of non-consent to summary trial, the court must proceed in accordance with section 18(1).

series.short: "New Plea Procedure for Young Offenders in Magistrates' Courts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation allows for a written procedure for indicating a plea in the Magistrates' Courts for certain young people under the age of 18.
* Simplified point 2: The procedure includes providing information to the accused, asking them to indicate their plea in writing, and allowing them to change their mind and withdraw their indication of plea.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also provides for the court to consider whether to exercise its powers under the Children and Young Persons Act 1963, and for the court to proceed in accordance with section 17ZA or 17A if the accused attains the age of 18 before the hearing.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation applies to certain offences other than those falling within section 51A(12) of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation allows for Criminal Procedure Rules to make provision about circumstances in which the written procedure does not have effect.

series.short: "New UK Law Allows Courts to Proceed Without Accused If They Fail to Appear"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 amends the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 to allow for proceedings to continue in the absence of the accused if they fail to appear at a hearing.
* Simplified point 2: The amendments provide for four conditions under which the court may proceed in the absence of the accused, including the presence of a legal representative, the serving of notice, and the accused's previous appearance.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also specifies that if no legal representative is present at the hearing, the court must proceed as if the accused had appeared and indicated a not guilty plea.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments apply to both the allocation hearing and the plea hearing, and the court must be satisfied that it is not contrary to the interests of justice to proceed in the absence of the accused.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation also includes provisions for the court to reopen the question of the mode of trial if the accused applies to do so, and for the accused to be taken to have indicated a not guilty plea if they fail to appear at a hearing.

series.short: "Criminal Justice Reforms: Streamlined Trials and Flexible Sentencing"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation amends the process for sending cases to the Crown Court for trial, allowing for more flexibility in the types of cases that can be sent and the procedures for sending them.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation introduces new provisions for sending children and young people to the Crown Court for trial, allowing for more tailored approaches to their treatment and rehabilitation.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation expands the types of offenses that can be sent to the Crown Court for trial, allowing for more efficient use of court resources and more effective management of cases.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation streamlines the process for sending cases to the Crown Court, reducing the need for multiple hearings and improving the efficiency of the court system.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation gives courts more flexibility in sentencing, allowing for more appropriate and effective punishment for offenders.

series.short: "Crown Court Sentencing Discretion Expanded"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 allows the Crown Court to send a case back to a magistrates' court for trial if the person has been sent to the Crown Court for an offence that is triable either way.
* Simplified point 2: The Crown Court must consider whether to send the person back to a magistrates' court and must give reasons if it decides not to do so.
* Simplified point 3: The Crown Court must take into account any other offences before it that appear to be related to the offence in question and must have regard to any allocation guidelines issued under the Coroners and Justice Act 2009.
* Simplified point 4: The Crown Court may give directions with respect to the custody of the accused or for the accused's release on bail until the accused can appear or be brought before the magistrates' court.
* Simplified point 5: There is no right of appeal against an order under subsection (1) of the Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022.

series.short: "Legislative Reforms for Youth Courts: Transfer of Cases to Crown Courts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislation allows a youth court to transfer cases to a magistrates' court or the Crown Court if the accused person turns 18 before the start of the trial.
* Simplified point 2: The youth court must give the accused person the opportunity to elect to be tried by the Crown Court, and if they do, the court must send them for trial to the Crown Court.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation provides for Criminal Procedure Rules to make provision about situations where a person is sent for trial under this section in relation to an alleged offence, and any other alleged offence that is related to the first offence.
* Simplified point 4: The provision that may be made as described in subsection (1E) includes provision for a person to be sent to the Crown Court for trial for the other alleged offence, even if it is a summary offence, and applying any other provision made by or under an Act about the sending of a person to the Crown Court for trial.

series.short: "Legislative Changes: Increased Maximum Terms of Imprisonment for Magistrates' Courts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation increases the maximum term of imprisonment for either-way offenses from 12 months to 6 months for summary convictions in magistrates' courts.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation allows the Secretary of State to amend the Sentencing Code to change the general limit on the power of magistrates' courts to impose custodial sentences, and to specify different limits for different types of offenses.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation applies to relevant legislation that provides for a maximum term of imprisonment of 12 months on summary conviction for an offence triable either way, and reads it as providing for a term of imprisonment not exceeding the general limit in a magistrates' court.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation allows the Secretary of State to make regulations to amend relevant primary legislation to spell out the effect of the changes made by the Act.

series.short: "Courts Overhaul: Streamlining Proceedings & Media Reporting"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 makes changes to the way courts handle written proceedings, allowing courts to provide information to parents or guardians of minors involved in the proceedings.
* Simplified point 2: The act also removes certain requirements for hearings about procedural matters, allowing courts to determine these matters without a hearing if appropriate.
* Simplified point 3: The act also makes changes to the way certain pre-trial hearings are reported in the media, allowing for more flexibility in how these hearings are handled.
* Simplified point 4: The act gives the Lord Chancellor the power to make regulations to make consequential or supplementary provision in relation to any provision of the chapter.
* Simplified point 5: The act also contains schedule 2 which contains amendments that are consequential on, or related to, the preceding provisions of the chapter.

series.short: "Online Dispute Resolution: Streamlining Court Proceedings with Technology"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 allows for online procedure in courts and tribunals for certain types of proceedings.
* Simplified point 2: The Online Procedure Rules must be accessible, simple, and easily expressed, and must support the use of innovative methods of resolving disputes.
* Simplified point 3: The Online Procedure Rules may require parties to participate in hearings by electronic means, but must also provide for non-electronic participation if the party is not legally represented.
* Simplified point 4: The Online Procedure Rules may authorize or require the final determination of proceedings to be disposed of by electronic means.
* Simplified point 5: The Online Procedure Rules may provide for circumstances in which proceedings are not or cease to be governed by the Rules, and for the proceedings to be governed by the applicable standard rules instead.
* Simplified point 6: The Online Procedure Rules may provide for proceedings to be taken in a court or tribunal that is not the one in which they would be taken if governed by the applicable standard rules.
* Simplified point 7: The Online Procedure Rules may not provide for proceedings to be taken in a court or tribunal that is not established under the law of the jurisdiction in which those proceedings are brought, or for an appeal to be taken in the court or tribunal whose judgment or decision is being appealed against.

series.short: ```Courts and Proceedings Regulation: Specifying Types of Civil Cases in England and Wales```
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 defines "specified kinds" of proceedings for the purpose of section 19, which includes various types of civil and tribunal proceedings in England and Wales.
* Simplified point 2: The Lord Chancellor has the power to specify the kinds of proceedings through regulations, and the regulations can be subject to concurrence requirement and affirmative resolution procedure.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can specify the legal basis, factual basis, value of the matter in issue, and the court or tribunal in which the proceedings are to be brought or continued.
* Simplified point 4: The purpose of specifying "specified kinds" of proceedings is to determine which proceedings are subject to the restrictions and requirements set out in the Act.

series.short: "Online Procedure Rule Amendments: Choice between Standard and Online Rules"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Lord Chancellor can make regulations to allow parties to choose whether to follow Online Procedure Rules or standard rules in certain court proceedings.
* Simplified point 2: The regulations can specify when and how parties can make this choice, and can also provide for circumstances where proceedings that were previously governed by Online Procedure Rules can be switched to standard rules.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can also provide for excluded proceedings, which are proceedings that are not governed by Online Procedure Rules, and for when these proceedings can be governed by standard rules instead.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations are subject to concurrence requirements and affirmative resolution procedure.

series.short: "Online Procedure Rules Committee Established for Judiciary Reform"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Online Procedure Rule Committee is established to create rules for online procedures in the judiciary.
* Simplified point 2: The Committee consists of judges, legal professionals, and lay advisors with experience in information technology.
* Simplified point 3: The Lord Chief Justice and the Lord Chancellor have appointing powers for the Committee, with consultation requirements.
* Simplified point 4: The Committee can appoint a chair and has expenses covered by the Lord Chancellor.
* Simplified point 5: The Committee is responsible for making rules for online procedures in the judiciary.

series.short: "Online Procedure Rule-Making Power of the Committee"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Online Procedure Rule Committee has the power to make rules for various types of proceedings in England and Wales, including civil, family, and employment proceedings.
* Simplified point 2: The Online Procedure Rule Committee can apply other procedural provisions to proceedings of a particular kind, even if they would not normally be applicable.
* Simplified point 3: The Online Procedure Rule Committee can modify or amend other procedural provisions when applying them to proceedings.
* Simplified point 4: The Online Procedure Rule Committee can refer to directions under various sections of enactments, such as the Civil Procedure Act 1997 and the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007, when making Online Procedure Rules.
* Simplified point 5: The Online Procedure Rule Committee can make Online Procedure Rules that apply to any extent, with or without modifications, and as amended from time to time.

series.short: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022: Streamlining Dispute Resolution with Electronic Data Transfer
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 allows for the transfer of information held for online dispute-resolution services to courts or tribunals via electronic means.
* Simplified point 2: The Act empowers the creation of Online Procedure Rules that can refer to specific services based on the actions of a particular person, such as those listed or certified by a particular person.
* Simplified point 3: The Act defines "online dispute-resolution service" as a service accessible by electronic means for resolving disputes without legal proceedings.
* Simplified point 4: The Act allows for the Rules to specify standards for online dispute-resolution services and for courts or tribunals to take into account steps parties have taken in relation to such services.

series.short: "Lord Chancellor's Regulatory Powers Under the Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Lord Chancellor has the power to change certain requirements related to the Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 Committee.
* Simplified point 2: The Lord Chancellor can make regulations to amend section 22 of the Act, as well as make consequential amendments to other provisions, but only with the concurrence of the Lord Chief Justice and the Senior President of Tribunals.

* Simplified point 4: The Lord Chief Justice may nominate a judicial office holder to exercise their function under subsection (2) of the section.
* Simplified point 5: Regulations made under this section are subject to negative resolution procedure.

series.short: "Online Procedure Rules: Consultation and Approval Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Online Procedure Rule Committee must consult with appropriate persons and hold a meeting before making Online Procedure Rules.
* Simplified point 2: The Online Procedure Rules must be signed by at least half of the members of the Committee, and submitted to the Lord Chancellor for approval.
* Simplified point 3: The Lord Chancellor may allow or disallow the Online Procedure Rules, taking into account the needs of persons who require online procedural assistance.
* Simplified point 4: If the Lord Chancellor disallows the rules, they must provide written reasons for doing so.
* Simplified point 5: Online Procedure Rules that are allowed by the Lord Chancellor come into force on a day directed by the Lord Chancellor and are subject to annulment by Parliament.

series.short: "Online Procedure Rule Changes by Lord Chancellor"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Lord Chancellor has the power to make changes to online procedure rules through regulations.
* Simplified point 2: These regulations can amend, repeal, or revoke any enactment, including enactments comprised in subordinate legislation.
* Simplified point 3: The Lord Chancellor must consult the Lord Chief Justice and the Senior President of Tribunals before making these regulations.
* Simplified point 4: The Lord Chief Justice can nominate a judicial office holder to exercise the function under subsection (3).
* Simplified point 5: Regulations that amend or repeal any provision of an Act are subject to affirmative resolution procedure.
* Simplified point 6: Any other regulations under this section are subject to negative resolution procedure.

series.short: "Regulatory Powers of the Lord Chancellor under the Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Lord Chancellor has the power to make regulations that are consequential or supplementary to any provision in Chapter 1 of the Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022.
* Simplified point 2: These regulations can amend, repeal, or revoke any provision of an Act passed before this Act or in the same Session, or any provision contained in subordinate legislation.
* Simplified point 3: Regulations that amend or repeal any provision of an Act are subject to affirmative resolution procedure, while other regulations are subject to negative resolution procedure.

series.short: "Lord Chancellor's Regulatory Approval Requirement"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Lord Chancellor must obtain the concurrence of a senior judge before making regulations related to civil or family proceedings in England and Wales.
* Simplified point 2: The Lord Chancellor must obtain the concurrence of a different senior judge before making regulations related to proceedings in various tribunals.
* Simplified point 3: The Lord Chief Justice may delegate their concurrence function to a judicial office holder.

EXPLANATION:

This extract of the Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 outlines the requirement for the Lord Chancellor to obtain the concurrence of senior judges before making regulations related to certain legal proceedings in England and Wales. Specifically, the Lord Chancellor must obtain the concurrence of the Lord Chief Justice for regulations related to civil and family proceedings, and the concurrence of the Senior President of Tribunals for regulations related to proceedings in various tribunals. Additionally, the Lord Chief Justice may delegate their concurrence function to a judicial office holder.

In simpler terms, this means that the Lord Chancellor must get approval from senior judges before making rules about legal proceedings in England and Wales. This is to ensure that the rules are fair and just, and that they do not interfere with the independence of the judiciary.

series.text:

summary:
The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 simplifies court procedures and streamlines the administration of justice. It includes provisions for:

Group 1: Streamlined Justice

* Quashing Orders: The Act allows for quashing orders to be made by the Upper Tribunal, which can include provision for the quashing not to take effect until a specified date or for removing or limiting any retrospective effect of the quashing.
* Finality of Upper Tribunal Decisions: The Act provides that the Upper Tribunal's permission-to-appeal decisions are final and not subject to judicial review in any other court.
* Exclusion of Supervisory Jurisdiction: The Act excludes the supervisory jurisdiction of the High Court or the Court of Session in relation to certain decisions of the Upper Tribunal, such as decisions involving questions of jurisdiction or procedural defects.
* Transitional Provision: The amendments made by the Act do not apply to decisions of the Upper Tribunal made before the day on which the Act comes into force.

Group 2: Automatic Online Convictions

* Overview: The automatic online conviction option is an alternative to the traditional court process for certain summary offences.
* Qualifying Conditions: The qualifying conditions for the automatic online conviction option are specified in regulations made by the Lord Chancellor, and include requirements such as the accused having attained the age of 18 years when charged and the required documents having been served on the accused.
* Penalties: The offender is liable to a fine of the amount specified for the offence, and may also be liable to other penalties such as penalty points, compensation, prosecution costs, and a surcharge.
* Timing and Status: The timing and status of conviction and penalty are determined in accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules, and the conviction is treated as if it had been imposed by the specified magistrates' court.

Other Provisions:

* Single Justice Procedure: The Act extends single justice procedure to corporations, allowing them to be dealt with by a single justice rather than a bench of magistrates.
* Written Indication of Plea: The Act allows for a person charged with an offense to indicate their plea in writing instead of appearing in court.
* Sentencing Guidelines: The Lord Chancellor has the power to make regulations about penalties etc under section 16I, and these regulations may specify different amounts of fines, compensation, prosecution costs, and surcharges for different offences.
